data.title: village, n. meanings, etymology and more
data.meta_description: village, n. meanings, etymology, pronunciation and more in the Oxford English Dictionary
data.text:
Factsheet

What does the noun village mean?

There are seven meanings listed in OED's entry for the noun village. See ‘Meaning & use’ for definitions, usage, and quotation evidence.

village has developed meanings and uses in subjects including

Entry status

OED is undergoing a continuous programme of revision to modernize and improve definitions. This entry has not yet been fully revised.

How common is the noun village?

About 90occurrences per million words in modern written English

175032176063177045178065179086180083181010018209418301101840110185011018609918701101880110189011019001001910991920991930100194099195011019601101970110198093199083200077201077

How is the noun village pronounced?

British English

VIL-ij

U.S. English

VIL-ij

Where does the noun village come from?

The earliest known use of the noun village is in the Middle English period (1150—1500).

OED's earliest evidence for village is from around 1386, in the writing of Geoffrey Chaucer, poet and administrator.

village is a borrowing from French.

Etymons: French village.

Nearby entries

Etymology

Summary

A borrowing from French.

Etymon: French village.

< Old French village, vilage (modern French village), = Provençal vilatge, Spanish village, Portuguese villagem (feminine), Italian villaggio < Latin villāticum, neuter singular of villāticus of or…

< Old French village, vilage (modern French village), = Provençal vilatge, Spanish village, Portuguese villagem (feminine), Italian villaggio < Latin villāticum, neuter singular of villāticus of or pertaining to a villa, < villa villa n.: see ‑age suffix. Compare late Latin villagium, vilatgium.

Meaning & use

Quotations

Hide all quotations

Contents

Earlier version

village, n. in OED Second Edition (1989)

In other dictionaries

villāǧe, n. in Middle English Dictionary

1.a.

A collection of dwelling-houses and other buildings, forming a centre of habitation in a country district; an inhabited place larger than a hamlet and smaller than a town, or having a simpler organization and administration than the latter. (Cf. the note to town n. I.4.)

Henne oure a myle, withinne a greet village.

G. Chaucer, Pardoner's Tale 225

He had not ryden but a whyle,..Or he was ware of a vyllage.

Sqr. lowe Degre 491

A Candrede in frensh and in Irysh, is a Porcion of grovnde that may contene an hundrid villachis.

J. Yonge, translation of Secreta Secretorum 184

In any Toune or other village not corporat.

Rolls of Parliament vol. VI. 184/1

They sayled Englande thorowe and thorowe Vyllage towne cyte and borowe.

Cocke Lorelles Bote sig. C.ijv

Much carting, ill tillage, makes som to flie village.

T. Tusser, Fiue Hundred Pointes of Good Husbandrie (new edition) f. 36

A large and ample village containing to the number of sixe thousand or mo families.

J. Pory, translation of J. Leo Africanus, Geographical Historie of Africa vii. 287

A wall'd Towne is more worthier then a village.

W. Shakespeare, As you like It (1623) iii. iii. 53

I remember not to haue seene a more pleasant village than this .

F. Moryson, Itinerary i. 51

Forth issuing on a Summers Morn to breathe Among the pleasant Villages and Farmes.., The smell of Grain.

J. Milton, Paradise Lost ix. 448

Consider also, that..the Customs of different Towns and Villages in the same Nation, are..contrary to each other.

I. Watts, Logick ii. iii. §4

O. Goldsmith, Deserted Village 1.

Wallacetown, a thriving and populous village in Ayrshire... This village nearly joins to the Newtown of Ayr, and, in 1792, contained..960 inhabitants.

Gazetteer of Scotland

A mere village has no claim to a municipal representation.

J. S. Mill, Considerations on Representative Government (1865) 115/1

When the meeting closed at one village, most of the people ran on to the next.

T. Coan, Life in Hawaii 43

in extended use

There are whole villages of these Vros inhabiting in the Lake in their boates of Totora, the which are tied together and fastened to some rocke.

E. Grimeston, translation of J. de Acosta, Naturall & Morall Historie Indies ii. vi. 94

phr

To express the Condition of an Honest Fellow and no Flincher, under the Effects of good Fellowship, he is said to..Come home by the Villages, this is Provincial, when a man comes home by the fields he meets nobody, consequently is sober, when he comes home by the Villages, he calls first at one house, then at another, and drinks at all.

Gentleman's Magazine December 559

A cot-house, a cottage; or (as some think) a village.

A street, a row of houses; (also) a village.

A collection of dwelling-houses and other buildings, forming a centre of habitation in a country district; an inhabited place larger than a…

An establishment where farming is carried on; †also, rarely, a group of such places, a village (obsolete). In later use: A country house with farm…

A (Dutch) village; formerly more or less naturalized in sense: Village, thorp, n. In South Africa, a small town.

poetic. A village.

A Welsh territorial and administrative unit consisting of a number of townships, largely superseded by the smaller tref by the end of the 12th…

1.b.

Applied jocularly to a large town or city, esp. London.

I used to keep a good prad here for a bolt to the village.

C. M. Westmacott, English Spy vol. I. 129

Living with Henley, No. 85, Newman Street... This is a very jolly little village, and I wish you were over here.

Du Maurier in Moscheles, In Bohemia (1897) 124

You had much better come up to the little village at once, Brown, and stay there while the coin lasts.

T. Hughes, Tom Brown at Oxford vol. II. xii. 218

Birmingham is called ‘the hardware village’.

Hotten's Slang Dictionary (revised edition) 334

A large or important municipality. With reference to English-speaking places: a municipality traditionally or officially designated a city, being…

A large or important municipality. In general use, and with reference to non-English-speaking places: a municipality of larger size or population…

singular and plural. An inhabited place; a country, realm, territory, domain; gen. a place. within wones, in wone (frequently as a tag) =…

Chiefly poetic. A castle, fortress; a city. in mote: among men. Obsolete.

Chiefly with of or possessive. A colony in relation to its founding city. Cf. mother city, n. 3 and compounds C.1a. Now rare.

= city, n.

Applied jocularly to a large town or city, esp. London.

A city as a technical entity or in contrast to a suburb, etc.

An urban area, a city. Cf. 'burb, n.

1.c.

Cambridge University slang. (See quot. 1864.)

A Cambridge term for a disreputable suburb of that town, viz., Barnwell, generally styled ‘the village’.

J. C. Hotten, Slang Dictionary (new edition) (at cited word)

1.d.

U.S. A minor municipality with limited corporate powers (see quots.).

A minimum population of three hundred, occupying not more than two square miles in extent, may by popular vote become incorporated as a ‘village’.

A. Shaw in J. Bryce, American Commonwealth (1888) vol. II. xlviii. 240

Of these villages and other minor municipalities there are various forms in different States. Ohio, for instance, divides her municipal corporations into (a) cities,..(b) villages, with two classes, the first of from 3000 to 5000 inhabitants, the second of from 200 to 3000; and (c) hamlets.

J. Bryce, American Commonwealth vol. II. xlviii. 247

1.e.

A small self-contained district or community within a city or town; spec. † (a) see sense 1c; (b) (with capital initial) = Greenwich Village adj.

implied in:

I wish you could meet some of my friends, who are not the kind of ‘Greenwich Villagers’ that you may have been thinking they were.

H. Crane, Letter 12 January (1965) ii. 170

Sue Borglum's pleasantry had been in the vein of the Village; Daisy's was in the taste of Broadway.

E. Wilson, I thought of Daisy i. 16

Peggy [Baird] will be here in a few days—I'd rather..she didn't step into a truly Greenich Village scene.

H. Crane, Letter 22 June (1965) iv. 376

London is made up of many villages.

M. Allingham, More Work for Undertaker xii. 156

Sketch of section of..cooperative multi-family for Holliswood, Queens, to be known as Hilltop Village.

New York Times 17 August viii–ix. 1w/5 (caption)

The word ‘village’ has a pleasant and attractive connotation for most of us, sufficiently so for it to be borrowed by many estate agents regardless of the context, and to be applied to self-contained neighbourhoods in towns (e.g. at Banbury and Washington, Co. Durham).

A. Thorburn, Planning Villages iv. 24

Hampstead—the loveliest of London's historical ‘villages’.

Harpers & Queen June 35/1

They call it a village but Skokie is geographically a middle-income suburb of Chicago with a population of 70,000.

Guardian Weekly 25 September 8/3

She had grown up in the Village, on West Ninth Street between Fifth and Sixth.

M. McMullen, But Nellie was so Nice i. iv. 23

An area of southern Manhattan in New York City.

transferred. Applied to (a) Newcastle, (b) New York.

With capital initials. The name of a district on the West Side of Manhattan, New York City, formerly an urban slum associated with poverty, violence…

slang. In full tenderloin district: applied to the police district of New York which includes the great mass of theatres, hotels, and places of…

The western part or side of something; the west.

The city of New York.

A small self-contained district or community within a city or town; spec. †(a) see sense 1c; (b) (with capital initial) = Greenwich Village, adj.

U.S. slang (originally Jazz). Usually with capital initial. With the. Originally: Harlem. Hence later: New York City. Cf. Big Apple, n. 4.

An area or city predominantly occupied by African Americans, or otherwise characterized by soul (soul, n. I.3c).

A division or district of a town or city, esp. that occupied by a certain group or community, or having a particular character or use. Sometimes…

(See quot. 1610.)

In France and French-speaking countries: a neighbourhood, a district (also in extended use). Also (with capital initial): spec. = Quartier Latin, n.

A small self-contained district or community within a town or city.

In Italy: a district or area (of a city). Also in extended use.

A part separated or divided off from the remainder; one of the portions into which a thing is cut or… (a) French History. One of the electoral…

In Spanish-speaking countries of South America: a community; a district of a town, etc.

Town Planning. A small sector of a larger urban area, provided with its own shops and other facilities. Frequently attributive (see compounds C.1a).

Chiefly British. A part of a town or city designated for a specific purpose; esp. a shopping area from which motor vehicles are excluded. Cf. pede…

A small self-contained district or community within a city or town; spec. †(a) see sense 1c; (b) (with capital initial) = Greenwich Village, adj.

2.

The inhabitants or residents of a village; the villagers.

The corte, the contre, wylage, and towne, Sayth..Of all prowde knauys thow beryst the belle.

J. Skelton, Poems against Garnesche in Poet Works (1843) vol. I. 127

The village all declar'd how much he knew.

O. Goldsmith, Deserted Village 207

The Village on their Pastor gaz'd, At once afflicted and amaz'd.

W. Combe, Second Tour Dr. Syntax xxvii. 29

A sleepy land..Where almost all the village had one name.

Lord Tennyson, Aylmer's Field in Enoch Arden, etc. 53

In Anglo-Saxon and Norman England: the inhabitants of an estate or village collectively. Cf. town, n. I.1b, I.3a. Obsolete.

The inhabitants or residents of a village; the villagers.

transferred. The people of a hamlet. (poetic.)

? a village community.

As many as a village contains; the whole of the people of a village.

3.

transferred (from 1). A small group or cluster of the burrows of prairie-dogs. Cf. town n. I.5b.

The Wishtonwish of the Indians, prairie dogs of some travellers,..reside on the prairies of Louisiana in towns and villages.

Z. M. Pike, Account of Expeditions to Sources of Mississippi (1810) ii. 156 (note)

I happened on a village of barking squirrels, or prairie dogs.

H. M. Brackenridge, Journal 3 June in Views of Louisiana (1814) 239

I learned that a burrow, or village, as it is termed, of prairie dogs had been discovered.

W. Irving, Tour on Prairies xxxii. 295

figurative and in extended use (from sense I.4a). A colony of prairie dogs (genus Cynomys), which occupies an extensive burrow system and can…

transferred (from 1). A small group or cluster of the burrows of prairie-dogs. Cf. town, n. I.5b.

= village, n. 3.

Forms

Variant forms

Middle English– village, Middle English vylage, villach, Middle English–1500s vyllage, Middle English–1600s vilage, 1500s wylage, Scottish willage, willaige, welage; also plural 1500s vyllagies, Scottish willagies.

Frequency

village is one of the 1,000 most common words in modern written English. It is similar in frequency to words like belief, connection, examine, latter, and weight.

It typically occurs about 90 times per million words in modern written English.

village is in frequency band 6, which contains words occurring between 10 and 100 times per million words in modern written English. More about OED's frequency bands

Frequency data is computed programmatically, and should be regarded as an estimate.

Frequency of village, n., 1750–2010

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Historical frequency series are derived from Google Books Ngrams (version 2), a data set based on the Google Books corpus of several million books printed in English between 1500 and 2010.

The overall frequency for a given word is calculated by summing frequencies for the main form of the word, any plural or inflected forms, and any major spelling variations.

For sets of homographs (distinct entries that share the same word-form, e.g. mole, n.¹, mole, n.², mole, n.³, etc.), we have estimated the frequency of each homograph entry as a fraction of the total Ngrams frequency for the word-form. This may result in inaccuracies.

Frequency of village, n., 2017–2023

* Occurrences per million words in written English

Modern frequency series are derived from a corpus of 20 billion words, covering the period from 2017 to the present. The corpus is mainly compiled from online news sources, and covers all major varieties of World English.

Contents

Sort by

One who lives in a village; now usually, a working-class inhabitant or native of a village.

Villages collectively.

A village with an economy chiefly or traditionally based on fishing.

transitive. To transform or reduce (a town) to the size of a village.

transitive. To make or reduce into a village.

A village where there is a post-stage or a post office.

A person like John Hampden (1594–1643), one without means or influence who opposes a powerful local person or organization (in imitation of quot…

? a village community.

A mode of expression usual in villages; a rustic phrase.

A little village.

(See quot.).

(intransitive) a. to settle down to a villeggiatura; b. to visit a village in a pastoral capacity.

transitive. To relocate (people) to planned villages, often compulsorily or forcibly, in an effort to exert control over previously scattered…

A village that is popular with holidaymakers, esp. one which has been specifically created as a holiday destination; (in later use) spec. (chiefly…

A village characterized by the presence of a manufacturing mill or mills.

Like or resembling a village or that of a village.

a. The idle talk of a village (see gossip, n. 4); b. a woman who gossips (see gossip, n. 3).

(In Ontario) a small village administered by an elected group of trustees rather than a council or municipal corporation.

Of or concerned with villages or village-life.

The chief house of a Malay village.

A collection of such dwellings.

A small self-contained district or community within a town or city.

The condition or status of a village; also, the system of village communities.

Somewhat village-like.

In the direction of the village.

Having no village.

= villagedom, n.

A residential community organized like a garden city (garden city, n. 2), esp. one provided by a company for its workforce; (also) an unspoilt…

= village, n. 3.

As many as a village contains; the whole of the people of a village.

A small encampment; spec. = douar, n.

A village consisting of tree-houses.

a. A village providing a high standard of housing, typically built to accommodate the workforce of a large employer (now historical) b. a small-scale…

a. A village where provisions, etc., may be bought, esp. one serving as the main or only shopping destination for a particular district; b. a…

One which is not liable to flooding.

(See quot. 1981).

a. Historical in Papua, a local man through whom the orders of the Australian administration were transmitted; b. a police constable stationed in a…

A village's communal water pump; frequently used allusively (cf. parish pump, n.).

(Esp. in Germany) a long, narrow village formed of buildings along either side of a main street.

A self-contained district within a city hosting the Olympics, providing accommodation and amenities for competitors and other people who have an…

The (often compulsory or forcible) relocation of people to planned villages by government and military authorities, in an effort to exert control…

The world considered as a single community brought together by high technology and international communications; also in extended use.

A settlement consisting of collective farms, established in Tanzania as part of the ujamaa socialist policy.

An urban area with a significant gay population and a high concentration of businesses catering primarily to this community.

General attributive.

C.1.

Simple attributive passing into adjective, = of or pertaining to, characteristic of, a village or villages; living in or belonging to a village; rural, rustic.

Frequently in poetry from the early 18th cent.

The Voinuchz or Græcian village men.

T. Washington, translation of N. de Nicolay, Nauigations Turkie iii. xiii. 95

The earlie village cocke, Hath twise done salutation to the morne.

W. Shakespeare, Richard III v. v. 163

Of the Village Dogge or house-keeper.

E. Topsell, Historie of Foure-footed Beastes 160

Enemies, that know not Why they are so; but like to Village Curres, Barke when their fellowes doe.

W. Shakespeare & J. Fletcher, Henry VIII ii. iv. 156

'Tis a plaine Village Girle Sir, but obedient.

P. Massinger, Great Duke of Florence ii. iii. sig. E

Might we but heare..Or sound of pastoral reed.., Or village cock Count the night watches to his featherie Dames.

J. Milton, Comus 12

Those Village-words, as I may call them, gives us a mean Idea of the thing.

J. Dryden, Ded. Æneis in translation of Virgil, Works sig. f2

Faithful as the simple Village Swain.

N. Rowe, Fair Penitent ii. i

She once, perhaps, in village plenty blest, Has wept at tales of innocence distrest.

O. Goldsmith, Deserted Village 327

The village-surgeon being then absent.

Mirror No. 42. ⁋4

No longer truth..disdain, But own the village life a life of pain.

G. Crabbe, Village ii. 25

One of the prettiest little village churches you ever saw in your life.

G. Colman, John Bull iv. ii. 62

But village notes could ne'er supply That rich and varied melody.

W. Scott, Rokeby v. 246

The domestic chaplain, the village doctor..and my uncle.

W. Scott, Rob Roy vol. I. v. 111

Learning should never pose a woman's head,..Whose wealth and beauty sanction higher aims, Than those of village-school instructing aims.

T. G. Fessenden, Ladies Monitor 124

The village shop, like other village shops, multifarious as a bazaar; a repository for bread, shoes, tea, cheese..for every thing, in short.

M. R. Mitford, Our Village vol. I. 6

Much might be said of village manners in America.

H. Martineau, Society in America vol. III. 91

They hurried through the village street.

C. Dickens, Barnaby Rudge xxv. 74

He is but a landscape-painter, And a village maiden she.

Lord Tennyson, Poems vol. II. 201

His masterpiece was his correct repetition of the Lord's prayer; which..would have done no discredit to many a village schoolmaster.

Cumberland Pacquet 1 August 3/1

To be a village-schoolmistress, free and honest.

C. Brontë, Jane Eyre vol. III. v. 121

The village people began to be reconciled presently to their lady.

W. M. Thackeray, Henry Esmond vol. I. ii. 58

A dark-eyed, dark-haired, shy, village beauty comes in.

C. Dickens, Bleak House (1853) vii. 61

A village boy, whom he caught misusing a poor dog.

C. M. Yonge, Heir of Redclyffe vol. I. vi. 94

A party of village children..gathering cowslips.

C. M. Yonge, Heartsease vol. I. i. 2

Mr. Hale..was anxious for the village postman, whose summons to the household was a rap on the back-kitchen window-shutter.

E. C. Gaskell, North & South vol. I. ii. 27

The house fronted the village green.

E. C. Gaskell, North & South vol. II. xxi. 281

Mr Rann's leathern apron and subdued griminess can leave no one in any doubt that he is the village shoemaker.

‘G. Eliot’, Adam Bede vol. I. i. ii. 28

That village wedding..where an awkward bridegroom opens the dance with a high-shouldered, broad-faced bride.

‘G. Eliot’, Adam Bede vol. II. ii. xvii. 5

An experienced eye would have fixed on him at once as the village blacksmith.

‘G. Eliot’, Adam Bede vol. II. ii. xviii. 36

The apartment was not much behind that at the village inn at Hiltonbury.

C. M. Yonge, Hopes & Fears vol. I. viii. 316

It was..interesting to observe his impression of the English village-life at Hiltonbury.

C. M. Yonge, Hopes & Fears vol. II. xviii. 347

The literati of the southern Slaves are not to be found among a higher class than the village clergy, and masters of village-schools.

R. D. in F. Galton, Vacation Tourists & Travel in 1860 114

The pleasures to which he had been introducing Gilbert, were not merely..the rabbit-shooting and rat-hunting of the farm, nor even the village cricket-match.

C. M. Yonge, Young Step-mother v. 58

Village-Communities in the East and West.

Maine (title)

Under the porch of the village store some desolate idlers..had clubbed their miserable leisure.

W. D. Howells, Chance Acquaintance i. 27

Whether I become the village parson..remains to be proved.

C. Rhodes, Letter in J. Flint, Cecil Rhodes (1974) ii. 24

He was followed to the grave by a large number of the village labourers.

Smiles in Longman's Magazine June 159

Every effort will be made to establish village industries, and I..hope..we may be able to restore some of the domestic occupations which steam has compelled us to confine to the great factories.

W. Booth, In Darkest England ii. iii. 138

The village Elders stand before him with joined hands to learn his Lordship's commands.

J. L. Kipling, Beast & Man in India viii. 194

The Eastern cat..is used in a frequently-quoted saying about doubtful matters. ‘If the Punchayat (village council) says it's a cat, why, cat it is.’

J. L. Kipling, Beast & Man in India xii. 316

The village shopkeeper, the maker of the ‘vinosity’ bread.

C. M. Yonge, Old Woman's Outlook 167

As soon as the villagers saw the smoke in the deserted shrine, the village priest climbed up..to welcome the stranger.

R. Kipling, Second Jungle Book 34

An expedition to play the zither and sing at a village fête.

C. M. Yonge, Long Vacation i. 5

I myself have had a village idiot exhibited to me as something irresistibly funny.

G. B. Shaw, Major Barbara Preface, in John Bull's Other Island 148

Dickson was at my bedside..and Pierce, the village policeman.

R. Marsh, Judith Lee i. 10

Hardy became a sort of village atheist brooding and blaspheming over the village idiot.

G. K. Chesterton, Victorian Age in Literature ii. 143

She was presently driven out of the place by..the baillie, and the village dogs.

J. Buchan, Salute to Adventurers i. 9

The village women, with little girls in clean pinafores clinging to their skirts.

‘O. Douglas’, Penny Plain xxv. 296

I'm afraid..that Modern Art wouldn't be quite suitable... It's only simple village folk, Mr. Ervine.

M. Kennedy, Ladies of Lyndon ii. 70

The Village Room is quite two miles off.

M. Kennedy, Ladies of Lyndon ii. 96

Down by the Village Room, where pictures are shown on Friday evenings..and into the village square again.

H. de Sélincourt, Cricket Match i. 10

Best cricket going, village cricket.

H. de Sélincourt, Cricket Match ii. 27

Like the village community of earlier times,..the school community..must engage in many practical enterprises.

L. Elmhirst in M. Yonge, Elmhirsts of Dartington (1982) vi. 138

It is high time to renounce This village idiocy.

C. Day Lewis, Transitional Poem ii. 24

Tomorrow was the village fête.

K. Boyle, Plagued by Nightingale (1931) xi. 87

She went many times..to the Chiswick Church in the little old village street beside the river.

A. P. Herbert, Water Gipsies xxiii. 350

He would put up at the village pub until the moment to pounce was due.

L. Golding, Magnolia Street i. vi. 107

She had formed a habit of ordering groceries..on a gigantic scale, from the village store.

A. Thirkell, High Rising i. 25

From the railroad station came crates and boxes with materials from New York and Vienna; the village children's hair was full of excelsior as they helped unpack them.

L. Bemelmans, Life Class iii. v. 246

‘Everybody who was anything’..kept a maid..stud grooms' wives, village schoolmasters' wives.

F. Thompson, Lark Rise x. 186

The position of a village schoolmistress was a trying one socially.

F. Thompson, Lark Rise xii. 225

To buy the printed likeness of the kitchen god at a village fair.

M. Cable & F. French, Gobi Desert 122

Emily Barton..has a mental picture of men as..smoking cigars, and in the intervals dropping out to do a few seductions of village maidens.

A. Christie, Moving Finger vii. 82

At that time village houses had no numbers or names.

F. Thompson, Still glides Stream ii. 18

He does nothing but read detective novels from the village library.

D. Smith, I capture Castle (U.K. edition) i. 5

A lively, exalted young novice..was formerly a village schoolteacher.

New Yorker 23 September 66/3

Such behaviour is a function of the social structure, with its emphasis on the village community and the kinship group.

R. Firth, Elements of Social Organization iv. 134

The village boys and girls still danced sedately.

M. Laski, Village i. 12

The village people..normally had their radios on all day.

M. Laski, Village iii. 52

Farmhouse and cottage furniture was made by the village carpenter.

G. E. Fussell & K. R. Fussell, English Countrywoman iv. 123

In France, village curés..exact fees from their parishioners.

S. Bedford, Sudden View i. x. 94

Celibacy might be asked of monk or friar but hardly from..a village parson.

A. Seton, Katherine vii. 119

He called upon the Kotwal—the village headman.

‘M. M. Kaye’, Shadow of Moon xxi. 309

The few hundred who..had been able to..travel farther than the county town or the village fair.

J. Cary in R. S. Surtees, Mr. Sponge's Sporting Tour p. xi

The small blank eyes mooned stolidly at me..it was like being gaped at by the village idiot.

J. R. Ackerley, We think World of You 40

The village elders were waiting for me on the little airstrip at Hoon.

‘A. Cordell’, Bright Cantonese ii. 28

Texts in glass cases hang outside.. and can be read by passengers in the village bus, which just stops there.

R. Blythe, Akenfield ii. 60

When the village shopkeeper sends things to out-of-the-way cottages..he's going to charge..something for the service.

R. Blythe, Akenfield iv. 89

The village chief himself asked us to a dinner of dried deer and shrimp crackers.

Listener 12 June 814/1

Most of the fishing would probably be done in the company of a village bobby.

O. Norton, Corpse-bird Cries i. 3

Such a simple life, isn't it, being a village copper?

O. Norton, Corpse-bird Cries v. 96

The annual general meeting of Portree Village Council was held in the Portree Hotel, at which there was a fairly large attendance.

Stornoway Gazette 13 January 7/2

Then we rushed him down to the village hall, which has been built by the energy of Len Edwards, our remarkable local inventor of laundry machinery.

R. Crossman, Diaries (1976) vol. II. 157

Family house on village green.

Country Life 9 October (Supplement) 26/1 (advertisement)

The cottage was set in restful countryside, a quarter of a mile from the village inn.

‘H. Carmichael’, False Evidence ii. 25

Local village shops may also substitute for day-to-day needs.

P. R. White, Planning for Public Transport vii. 142

Unhonoured assignations with village beauties.

P. Van Greenaway, Man called Scavener ii. 21

We had the funeral on the Saturday... The village church was absolutely packed.

J. Porter, Dead Easy for Dover ii. 25

The village girls used to go there at the new moon and wish. Like a wishing well.

‘J. Melville’, Axwater ii. 57

The village doctor..saw her once in a while for measles and mumps.

‘S. Kemp’, Goodbye, Pussy x. 125

The village Postmistress, who delighted in gossip.

G. Sims in Winter's Crimes 12 149

Women who..were ducked in village ponds to find out whether or not they were witches.

M. Warner, Joan of Arc i. 20

The village postman..had seen Kemp that morning.

E. Clark, Send in Lions xiii. 121

On Christmas Eve the village priests came to hold a vespers service.

A. Edwards, Sonya xi. 175

We wore heavy black boots made by the village shoemaker.

C. Miller, Childhood in Scotland 63

Rekindling village life in Chelsea.

Times 29 January–4 February (Saturday Supplement) 4/4 (caption)

C.2.

† Attributive, = village-like; of the size or constitution of a village. Obsolete. rare.

In populous Cityes, not in village Townes, for no Bishops were ever suffered to be in village Townes.

Bishop J. Taylor, Of Sacred Order Episcopacy (1647) 89

C.3.

In objective and objective genitive, instrumental, locative, or other combinations, as village-founder, village-haunter; village-based, village-born, village-dwelling, village-lit, village-made adjs.

These..wrought more With village-haunters.

G. Daniel, Trinarchodia: Henry V ccxcix, in Poems (1878) vol. IV. 175

The Jès were all Igrâwy, that is village-dwelling Arabs, who cultivate the soil.

G. P. Badger, Nestorians vol. I. 343

The landscape of village-lit plain and forest-darkened height.

W. D. Howells, Their Wedding Journey ix. 242

The local hero or eponymous village-founder was the man who cut down the jungle.

Cornhill Magazine January 35

Each village-made crook had an individuality, that of the blacksmith.

R. Jefferies, Nature near London 221

The many village-born men in towns.

Daily News 11 September 3/4

In this situation the village-based independent may score over the larger operator.

P. R. White, Planning for Public Transport vii. 140

C.4.

Special combinations.

A person like John Hampden (1594–1643), one without means or influence who opposes a powerful local person or organization (in imitation of quot…

(See quot.).

a. The idle talk of a village (see gossip, n. 4); b. a woman who gossips (see gossip, n. 3).

The chief house of a Malay village.

= village, n. 3.

(See quot. 1981).

a. Historical in Papua, a local man through whom the orders of the Australian administration were transmitted; b. a police constable stationed in a…

A village's communal water pump; frequently used allusively (cf. parish pump, n.).

C.5.

(With capital initial.) Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Greenwich Village. U.S.

She's not a Village artist... She was very wealthy once.

T. Sterling, House without Door iv. 41

He wore a sort of Village uniform—corduroys and a turtle-necked dark jersey.

M. McMullen, But Nellie was so Nice i. i. 7

Entry history for village, n.

Revision of the OED is a long-term project. Entries in oed.com which have not been revised may include:

Revisions and additions of this kind were last incorporated into village, n. in July 2023.
